content: The "Child Gun Safety and Gun Access Prevention Act of 2000" aims to increase youth gun safety by raising the age of handgun eligibility and prohibiting youth from possessing semiautomatic assault weapons. Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to raise the age limit for handgun eligibility and prohibit individuals under 21 years of age from possessing semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices. The amendment to Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code raises the age limit for handgun eligibility and prohibits individuals under 21 years of age from possessing semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices. It also includes provisions for temporary possession and self-defense situations. The amendment to Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code raises the age limit for handgun eligibility to 21 years and prohibits individuals under 21 from possessing certain firearms. It allows temporary transfer or use of a handgun by individuals aged 18-21 for specific purposes like employment or ranching/farming activities. The amendment to Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code raises the age limit for handgun eligibility to 21 years and prohibits individuals under 21 from possessing certain firearms. It allows temporary transfer or use of a handgun by individuals aged 18-21 for specific purposes like employment, ranching/farming activities, target practice, hunting, or handgun instruction in accordance with State and local laws. Additionally, paragraph (4) is amended to replace "juvenile" with "person who is less than 21 years of age". SEC. 3. Enhanced penalty for youth possession of handguns and semiautomatic assault weapons and for the transfer of such weapons to youth. Section 924(a)(6) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to impose fines and imprisonment for juveniles violating section 922(x), with harsher penalties for subsequent violations or those committed after a prior delinquency adjudication or conviction for a serious violent felony. Adults who knowingly violate section 922(x) face fines, imprisonment up to five years, or both, with increased penalties if they transfer specified weapons to minors. The amendment to section 924(a)(6) of title 18, United States Code imposes fines and imprisonment for transferring a handgun, ammunition, semiautomatic assault weapon, or large capacity ammunition feeding device to a person under 21 who intends to use it in a crime of violence, with penalties of up to 10 years in prison. SEC. 4. Gun storage and safety devices required for all firearms. Sec. 4 mandates gun storage and safety devices for all firearms. Section 922 of title 18, US Code, prohibits licensed firearms dealers from selling to individuals without providing a secure gun storage or safety device. Violations can result in license suspension, revocation, or a fine up to $10,000. Section 922(z) of this chapter prohibits licensed firearms dealers from selling to individuals without secure gun storage or safety devices. Violations can lead to license actions reviewed under section 923(f). Inconsistent provisions in sections 923(d)(1) and 923(e) are repealed. Licensed firearms dealers are prohibited from selling to individuals without secure gun storage or safety devices. Violations can result in license actions. Section 119 of the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State, the Judiciary, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1999 is amended by striking subsection (d), with the effective date being 180 days after enactment. SEC. 5. RESPONSIBILITY OF ADULTS FOR DEATH AND INJURY CAUSED BY CHILD ACCESS TO FIREARMS. Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include provisions regarding the responsibility of adults for child access to firearms. The term 'child' refers to an individual under 18 years old. Any person who keeps a loaded firearm within premises they control, knowing a child could access it and use it to cause harm, will be held accountable. If a child uses a firearm to cause harm, the responsible adult could face up to 3 years in prison, a fine, or both. Exceptions include if the firearm was secured, if the person is a peace officer or in the military, or if the child used the firearm in self-defense. The person can keep a firearm without fear of a child being present if it is secured or used in self-defense. Requirement for children to be accompanied by an adult at gun shows. The amendment to Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, requires children under 18 to be accompanied by an adult at gun shows. Violation of this rule will result in penalties according to state laws on child abandonment. Additionally, grants are provided for gun safety education programs. The Attorney General can grant funds to local governments for gun safety classes for parents and children. Applications must be submitted with assurances on fund usage and class availability. Gun safety classes will be offered at convenient times for parents, including evenings and weekends. The Attorney General will issue necessary regulations for this section. Education: Nationwide firearms safety programs should be provided by each school district for students in grades K-12. Consultation with a certified firearms instructor is recommended for curriculum development. Participation in the program should not be mandatory if a parent provides written notice to exempt their child.
